process_ncsmc_output.py¶

A module to consolidate all functions in ncsmc_python, so you can just feed it the NCSMC output, and it gives you a bunch of useful stuff:

  • plots of all resonances

  • spaghetti plot with interesting resonances

  • level scheme plot

ncsmc_python.process_ncsmc_output.add_nmax_data(Nmax_list)¶

Add data to be plotted on the level scheme for each Nmax in Nmax_list

Nmax_list:

list of floats

ncsmc_python.process_ncsmc_output.add_resonances(Nmax, eigenphase_flipped, eigen_channels_str, eigen_channel_titles, phase_flipped, phase_channels_str, bound_energies, bound_titles)¶

Use eigenphase file to add details about resonances (widths, energies, …) to the overall lists of data to be plotted.

Also takes phase data for plotting purposes if needed

Nmax:

float

eigenphase_flipped:

path to flipped eigenphase file

eigen_channels_str:

string, the contents of the csv file with the details of interesting resonances (width, energy, state)

eigen_channel_titles:

list of strings, again representing channels but formatted nicely

phase_flipped, phase_channels_str:

Same idea as all the eigen ones but for phase. Last one may be None.

bound_energies:

list of floats, energies of bound states

bound_titles:

list of strings, titles of bound states

ncsmc_python.process_ncsmc_output.eigen_help_str = "\nFirst, take a look at the PNGs_phase files, to figure out which\nchannels are interesting\n\n(just look at the graph, if you see a swoop up, it's interesting)\n\nThen, figure out which columns in the eigenphase file those match with.\n(they should have the same J, pi, T, but may have a different column #)\n\nThen, open up resonances_eigenphase_Nmax_[#].csv and copy the lines\nassociated with those channels.\n\nWhen you're done, the file should look\nsomething like this:\n\n3,+,3,1,strong\n3,+,3,3,strong\n3,-,3,3,strong\n5,-,3,4,none\n5,+,3,4,strong\n\n[lines copied from the eigenphase csv file, one blank line at the end]\n\n"¶

eigen_help_str is the help text displayed to the user when they have to look at the phase shift plots and select which channels are important.

Note that it looks a whole lot better in the python file than online.

ncsmc_python.process_ncsmc_output.get_experimental()¶

Grab experimental data from a file which must be prepared in advance.

The path to the file is saved above as experiment

ncsmc_python.process_ncsmc_output.make_phase_plots_too = True¶

To run process_ncsmc_output.py, you must have an experiment.txt file stored at the above location.

That file should look something like this:

[start of file] Data is from the TUNL images and widths are eyeballed (http://www.tunl.duke.edu/nucldata/figures/09figs/09_03_2004.gif)

States are given in the form “Energy Width J parity T” but with commas. Don’t want to mess up the parsing by using commas elsewhere!

Li9 THRESH 4.0639 0,0,1.5,-,1.5 2.691,0,0.5,-,? 4.296,0.2,2.5,-,? 5.38,0.4,?,?,? 6.43,0,?,?,? [end of file]

The stuff at the top of the file isn’t necessary, just helpful for a reader. The program just looks for the THRESH line, and all lines with commas. Use question marks for values that are not known experimentally.

ncsmc_python.process_ncsmc_output.phase_help_str = "\nYou have opted to plot (non-eigen)phase data too,\nby setting make_phase_plots_too = True.\n\nTake a look at the PNGs_phase files, to figure out which\nchannels are interesting\n\n(just look at the graph, if you see a swoop up, it's interesting)\n\nThen, open up resonances_phase_Nmax_[#].csv and copy the lines\nassociated with those channels.\n\nWhen you're done, the file should look\nsomething like this:\n\n3,+,3,1,strong\n3,+,3,3,strong\n3,-,3,3,strong\n5,-,3,4,none\n5,+,3,4,strong\n\n[lines copied from the phase csv file, one blank line at the end]\n\n"¶

phase_help_str is just like eigen_help_str, but for phase plots.

ncsmc_python.process_ncsmc_output.plot_scheme()¶

Plot a level scheme! Grab all data and call scheme_plot.plot_multi_levels()

ncsmc_python.process_ncsmc_output.select_interesting_channels(Nmax)¶

Get interesting channels (i.e. those channels which contain resonances) by using human inputs in files.

Nmax:

float
